main event: At Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico on February 19, 1950 at 1355Z, a cigar-shaped, luminous object was observed for 44 minutes by Major William J. Lloyd and other credible witnesses. No physical evidence was found, and the conclusion was that the object was likely Astro (Venus).
interesting points: The object appeared to be very bright and at times reflected the light of the sun.
It moved rapidly back and forth across the sky, speeding up and slowing down alternately, and at one point took on the appearance of an ice-cream cone.

Checks were made with various departments, but no official investigation was required as per Air Force Regulations and no evidence of a celestial phenomenon or planet that could account for the sighting was found.
The object appeared to have good control, and the manner of its disappearance was such that the observers were uncertain whether it was still visible.
The sighting was reported based on a directive to report all sightings of unidentified flying objects, and a detailed description of the witnesses' reliability, sobriety, and hobbies was included.
sighted object: cigar-shaped, luminous object in the sky
location: Holloman Air Force Base, New Mexico
witnesses: Major William J. Lloyd and other credible military personnel
photographs: no photographs were included in the report
